scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: Constituted in successive stages over a period of 60 years, this impressive collection was gathered by Prokofiev himself and by members of his family. During his prolonged stay in the West from 1918 to 1936, Prokofiev accumulated a large personal archive. When he returned to Moscow, he took only those papers and manuscripts he judged necessary for his life in the Soviet Union. Everything else was left in the care of close Parisian friends and his publisher, Edition Russe de Musique.

These papers remained in France until 1974 when Mme. Lina Prokofiev, having returned to Paris, was able to reclaim them. In the years that followed, Lina devoted her considerable energy to promoting Prokofiev and to tracking down his personal effects and papers, thus increasing considerably her husband's collection. She created The Serge Prokofiev Foundation in 1983.

After her death in 1989 at age 91, the work continued, with tremendous energy when Noelle Mann established the Prokofiev Archive in 1994 at Goldsmiths College, London. What has come to Columbia with the material from London are high quality photocopies of some of Prokofiev's manuscript scores, and copies of his correspondence and business papers, along with Lina Prokofiev's personal archive, including materials gathered for a planned biography of her husband, and those of Oleg Prokofiev, their younger son, relating to his own work and to his father's music.

Manuscript Resources: Joining the Archive for the first time, following storage in Paris, are a major group of the composer's original autograph music manuscripts, and the originals of his correspondence and business records dating from 1917 through 1936.

The music manuscripts in the Archive include sketches, drafts and full manuscript scores for 42 works principally composed during the years that Prokofiev spent in the United States, Germany and France. They include, among other works, his Symphony Nos. 3 and 4, his operas The Gambler and The Fiery Angel, the Concerto for Piano Nos. 4 and 5, the ballets Sur le Borysthene and Le Pas d'Acier, the Sonata for Two Violins, and String Quartet No. 1. Also in the Archive are three notebooks of musical ideas kept by Prokofiev during the years 1919, 1929 and 1931.

The Archive also contains the originals of Serge Prokofiev's correspondence and business papers, dating from 1917 through 1936, arranged by date. The range of correspondents is vast, including conductors such as Albert Coates, Sir Henry Wood, Sergei Koussevitzky, Hermann Scherchen, and Ernest Ansermet; soloists Joseph Szigeti, Pablo Casals, Robert Soetens, and Fedor Chaliapin; composers Igor Stravinsky, Nikolai Miaskovsky, and Maurice Ravel; directors Vsevolod Meyerhold and Alexander Tairov; Ballets Russes impresario Serge Diaghilev; and chess grandmaster Jose Capablanca. Business papers include financial materials such as bills and accounts, legal papers, and correspondence concerning concerts in the United States, France, Italy, Spain, England, the Soviet Union, and Germany, as well as materials relating to the publication and copyright of Prokofiev's work.

Published Material: Also in the archive is the largest collection of published material on Prokofiev in the West, including some 500 scores (including many rare and first editions), over 400 books (mainly in English and Russian, but also in French and German), periodicals and articles on Prokofiev, and nearly 500 concert programs. The audiovisual collection contains almost 800 audio recordings on CD, LP and cassette, and 65 video/DVD recordings.

Website: The website of the Serge Prokofiev Foundation, www.sprkfv.net, contains further information about the life and works of the composer and the Archive. There is also information about the journal of the Prokofiev Foundation, Three Oranges, including some sample full-text articles, and information regarding subscriptions.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p:
Material is arranged in eight series:
Series I: Music Manuscripts
Subseries I.1: Orginals
Subseries I.2: Photocopies
Subseries I.3: Microiflm
Subseries I.4: Digital copies
Series II: Personal Papers
Subseries II.1: Personal and Business Correspondence
Subseries II.2: Financial material
Subseries II.3: Miscellaneous
Series III: Published Material (Research Support Collection)
Subseries III.1: Scores
Subseries III.2: Books
Subseries III.3: Periodicals
Subseries III.4: Concert Programs
Series IV: Audio and Visual Material
Series V: Photographs
Series VI: Newspaper Clippings
Series VII: Family Papers
Subseries VII.1: Lina Prokofiev Papers
Subseries VII.2: Oleg Prokofiev Papers
Series VIII: Other Collections
Subseries VIII.1: Georgii Gorchakov Collection
Subseries VIII.2: Christopher Palmer Collection
Subseries VIII.3: Lázár Collection
Subseries VIII:4: Sir Edward Downes Collection
Subseries VIII.5: Noëlle Mann Collection

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: The Serge Prokofiev Foundation Archive is accessed by arrangement with the Project Archivist for the Prokofiev Archives

acqinfo.head: Acquisition
acqinfo.p: The Serge Prokofiev Archive is on deposit with the Rare Book and Manuscript Library by the Serge Prokofiev Foundation.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of specific item; Date (if known); Serge Prokofiev Archive; Box and Folder; Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Columbia University Library.

userestrict.head: Restrictions on Use
userestrict.p: Copyright remains with the creator and his/her heirs. The responsibility to secure copyright permission rests with the patron.

scopecontent.p: Sketches, drafts and full manuscript scores for xx works principally composed during the years that Prokofiev spent in the United States, Germany and Paris. Original manuscripts include, among other works, his Symphony Nos. 3 and 4, his operas The Gambler, and The Fiery Angel, the Concerto for Piano Nos. 4 and 5, the ballets Sur le Borysthene and Le Pas d'Acier, the Sonata for Two Violins, and String Quartet No. 1. Also in the Archive are three notebooks of musical ideas kept by Prokofiev during the years 1919, 1929 and 1931.

note.p: Notes: 1914 clean score in black ink with revisions from 1934 in pencil. The French title also appears in pencil, while the Russian title is in ink. End dated February, 15 1934, Paris. The verso of the cover page contains a very short piano sketch of an unidentified passage.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

note.p: Standard title: Sonata for Two Violins
Annotations: black ink; red ink; pencil;

Notes: Although the score is not stamped "Gravé," this appears to be a final version for engraving. Front page bears the address "5, rue Valentin Haüy, Paris XV, France." Score includes markings for bowing and fingering, as well as some changes to tempo and dynamic markings, annotations and very sparing changes to musical material.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil

Notes: Prepared for publication under plate numbers R.M.V 608 and R.M.V. 609. Stamped "Gravé" in red. Pagination marked in pencil. Front page has an annotation reading "Prière de graver en notre format ordinaire. Faire suivre la pagination, mais commencer chaque morceau en haut de la page."
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Увертюра на еврейские темы/Ouverture in Yiddish Themes/ Ouverture sur Thèmes Juifs1922;1934

note.p: Standard title: Overture on Hebrew Themes

Notes: Printed score for the sextet version with Prokofiev's annotations for orchestration as well as some additional parts written out in pencil in the margins. End dated May 31, 1934, Bugrah. Published by Breitkopf & Hartel, Leipzig in 1922 under plate number A. 10309. G.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Three Pieces, for piano (No. 3: Sonatine pastorale)
Notes: Clean draft in black ink with sparing corrections added in pencil. The end of the score indicates that the piece is 4 minutes long.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Two Sonatinas for Piano (No. 1)
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil
Notes: Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. Includes metronome markings. Prepared for publication under plate number R.M.V. 541.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Two Sonatinas for Piano (No. 2)
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil
Notes: Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. Includes metronome markings. Prepared for publication under plate number R.M.V. 542.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Seven, They Are Seven
Annotations: pencil; red crayon; blue crayon; blue pen

Notes: Printed score and appended corrections. Score published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). Subsequently marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page of the printed score is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. The last seven leaves contain autograph revisions and corrections.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Suite from The Prodigal Son
Content type: Full score; Short score

Notes: Composite sketch with references to original ballet score. Additions include sparing notation in connecting parts and very few inclusions of new instruments and melodies. Full ending of the fifth movement written out. Front page dated August 15, 1930. Fifth movement end dated October 21, 1930, Paris.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon

Notes: Composite score with reference to the parts of the score of the Fiery Angel that have been used to make up the symphony. The score contains many insertions and rearrangements, but few corrections when it comes to notes and rhythms. Movements end dated as follows: - I: September 6, 1928 - II: September 18, 1928 - III: November 3, 1928 - IV: September 25, Vétraz The last two folia contain insertions to earlier parts of the score.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; blue crayon; red crayon
Notes: Late draft with a few insertions to different parts of the score and some corrections to musical material. Front page dated December 7, 1928. Fourth number end dated March 14, 1929.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil
Content type: Piano score; Original workings

Notes: Movements end dates and running times as follows: - I: July 16, 1930 (5.5 mins) - II: July 21, 1930; Paris (4.5 mins) - III: July 15, 1930 (7 mins) Some parts (beginnings, ends, pivotal points) drafted clearly. The rest is sketched roughly. The last four leaves contain sketches and a working out of a few bars of the full version. Folios 8r and 9v contain a clean sketch for Sur le Borysthène (Number 11 - Act 2, scene 2 Mime scene)
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: black ink; blue ink; pencil;
Content type: Piano score with instrumental annotations; Original workings

Notes: First leaf contains a sketch of the beginning and end of the first movement (Moderato). The back of the next folio contains a partial transposition one tone down of a portion of the movement. The opening theme of the second movement (Nocturne - Larghetto) is sketched several times. Parts of the third movement (Dance - Allegro energico) are sketched in pencil. End dated August 4, 1925. Final sheet contains ending of Matelote movement of Trapèze (beginning present in BN#23494). The sheet is, however, marked "Divertimento, 1st version."
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Six Pieces, for Piano
Annotations: black ink; blue ink; pencil

Notes: Final version for engraving. Prepared for publication under plate numbers R.M.V. 529 - R.M.V. 534. Pagination and line splits (as well as a few very minor annotations) marked in pencil. Originally the titles were marked with numbers, but subsequently the movement numbers have been crossed out. A note in pencil in upper left margin on first page reads "Gravez en format ordinaire. Pagination separée" [Engrave in ordinary format. Separate pagination] and a few of the movements have notes that ask for space to be left for title and dedication. Two of the movements have dedications: The Scherzino to Nicolas Orloff and the Scherzo to Vladimir Horowitz. Folio 14r contains a sketch for another piece. Dates indicated are: I. 1931 (1928) II. [Date erased] III. [No date] IV. 1920 (1931) V. 1930 (1931) VI. 1909(1931)
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil;
Notes: Drafts of all numbers except 2-5, 7, 10-14, 22, 23, 34, and 35.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Content type: Piano score; Original workings
Notes: Includes sketches for numbers 2, 10, 16, 18, 19, 24, 26, 27, 29, 35, 44. Contains some instrumental annotations.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; red crayon; blue crayon;

Notes: Full copyist version of incidental music with autograph annotations and corrections. Most corrections are about dynamic and tempo markings as well as reorchestration, but certain bars are crossed off and corrected. Full corrected versions of numbers 2 and 28 are appended at the end. First page is marked (but then crossed out) "А. Я. Таирову, камерный театр, Тверской бульвар, Москва" [A. Y. Tairov, Chamber theater, Tverskoy boulevard, Moscow]
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil; green crayon
Content type: Piano score with instrumental annotations; Original workings
Notes: Piano sketch in black ink with notes in pencil for orchestration. The last folio contains a sketch, which is identified as an insertion, but does not seem to be from the piece.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Arrangement of Twelve Russian Folk Songs (No. 4: White Snow)
Annotations: blue ink; black ink; pencil

Notes: Clean score with very few corrections in pencil. On the first page there is a marking saying that the song should be transposed half a tone up (to D major). This is not true of the final, published version, which is in B major. Folder says 5, but this is 4
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

Notes: Draft dating from 1931 with references to 1916 opera score. Numerous notes and corrections in composer's hand. Fourth movement end dated December 27, 1931.

Notes: On the first page, the working title "Un Dimanche soir" has been crossed out and the title На Днепре [Na Dnepre] has been written out in the composer's hand. A few of the movements are not in the same order as in final score. What is marked as movement 2 here is movement 4 in the final version; movements 5 and 6 are switched in the final version. Movements end dated as follows: - II: October 23, 1930 - IV: October 27, 1930 - V: November 6, 1930 - X (final): February 12, 1931; Paris
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

did.unittitle: Un Dimanche Soir (crossed out); Au (crossed out and corrected to Sur) le Borysthène; На Днепре1930

note.p: Notes: Piano reduction of the ballet score. Appears to be the final version before engraving for the rehearsal score, to be published under plate number R.M.V 520 (Pages are marked up in pencil for engraving, although there is no red stamp indicating that this was indeed engraved). Movements do not appear in the same order as in the final version. Pencil markings indicate the new order of movements. Front page dated 1930. End dated February 12, 1931; Paris. On the first page, the working title "Un Dimanche soir" has been crossed out. Then the title "Au Borysthène" has been written in blue ink. Finally the word "Au" has been crossed out in pencil and corrected to "Sur le."
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France
Standard title: Concerto for Piano No. 4
Annotations: blue ink; red crayon; pencil

Notes: Orchestral parts only. No piano part. First page dated 1931. Third movement end dated September 8, 1931; Ciboure. Final movement end dated September 11, 1931; Ciboure. Over certain bars, there are page numbers (perhaps those of the piano draft?) marked in red crayon and in pencil.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

Notes: Corrections to the score (particularly to the end of the symphony). This pertains to the 1929 version (op. 47), not the revised 1947 (op. 112) version. Corrections done in two parts. Notes: Second version of opera. Final version for engraving. Stamped 'Gravé' in red. Pagination marked in pencil. German text written above the staff in blue ink. French and Russian below in black. Possible cuts to the opera indicated. Act 2 end dated December 12, 1927. Whole work end dated March 6, 1928, Paris A few of the folia contain one-word Russian annotations in a very rough, almost childlike hand that does not look like Prokofiev's. A few of the folia contain paste-overs and corrections. In one instance, there is an added page to be inserted at an earlier spot. In a few of the margins, as well as on the verso of folio 15, the composer has worked out endings of scenes in pencil.
Previous holding library: Bibliothèque nationale de France

Notes: After a title page, the first seven pages contain revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. Pages 21 and 26 of the original present in duplicate.

Standard title: Sonata for Solo Cello

Notes: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Notes: After a title page, the first seven slides contain revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French translation by Louis Laloy is written out. Rendered in different order than the original. (Corrections rendered out of order.)

Standard title: Sonata for Solo Cello

Notes: Work completed by Vladimir Blok, based on Prokofiev's sketches. Includes a preface by Blok explaining the reconstructive process. The parts by Prokofiev are the exposition and the beginning of the development. Blok has continued the development, appended a literal reprise of the first part of the exposition, connected it with a surviving sketch of the recapitulation and then recapitulated the remaining themes of the exposition. Prokofiev's tempo and dynamic markings are indicated with asterisks. Published in Moscow in 1973. Fingerings and bowings in this edition by N. (probably Natalia) Gutman. Wrong opus number printed on the title page, and then corrected in pencil (on the copy) to 134. The title page contains the following hand-written inscription in Russian dated August 21, 1973 from Blok to one Lola Feigin: "Дорогому Лёля Фейгину от одного из многих отнюдь не-Прокофьевых с сердечнни приветем."
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London

Standard title: Seven, They Are Seven

Notes: After a title page, the first seven pages contain autograph revisions and corrections to a score (also present in the copy) published in 1922 by the State Publishing House in Moscow (Государственное Музыкальное Издательство). The printed score is also marked up with corrections and revisions in Prokofiev's hand. Each page is stamped "Societé des auteurs, May 16, 1924." There are a number of dates on the score: The original date of composition printed inside is 1917, the cover notes date of publication as 1922, and the title page has the date 1918 printed. In the margin of the title page two more dates are written: сочинил (composed): 1917 and пересмотренный (revised) 1933. A marking in blue crayon on the first page reads "36 parts. Conseil du 30 avril 1924." The title page bears the original subtitle "Кантата" [Cantata], which has been crossed out and corrected to Заклинанiе [Incantation]. Under the printed Russian text the French transaltion by Louis Laloy is written out. Rendered in different order than the original. Corrections rendered out of order.
Previous holding library: Serge Prokofiev Archive at Goldsmiths College, University of London
